Title: Cholinergic innervation of the monkey amygdala: An immunohistochemical analysis with antisera to choline acetyltransferase
Abstract: The organization of the cholinergic innervation of the macaque monkey amygdaloid complex was investigated by means of immunohistochemical techniques and either a polyclonal antiserum or a monoclonal antibody directed against the specific synthetic enzyme choline acetyltransferase (ChAT). Adjacent series of sections were processed histochemically for the demonstration of the degradative enzyme acetylcholinesterase (AChE) or for cell bodies with thionin. The density of ChAT immunoreactivity differed substantially among the various nuclei and cortical regions of the amygdala. In general, the distribution of ChAT immunoreactivity paralleled the pattern of AChE staining. One notable exception was the presence of AChE containing cell bodies in addition to AChE positive fibers within nearly all of the nuclear and cortical regions. In contrast, ChAT immunoreactivity was associated only with fibers and terminals. The highest density of ChAT immunoreactive fibers and terminals was consistently observed in the magnocellular subdivision of the basal nucleus. Staining was substantially less dense in the more ventrally situated parvicellular subdivision. Medially, in the adjacent accessory basal nucleus, immunoreactive fibers and terminals were densest in the magnocellular and superficial subdivisions and least prominent in the parvicellular subdivision. Of the deep nuclei, the lateral nucleus generally obtained the least ChAT immunoreactive terminals and processes. Only its more densely cellular ventrolateral portion contained appreciable fiber and terminal staining. One of the more distinctive patterns of ChAT immunoreactivity was seen in the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract. Here, ChAT positive fibers formed pericellular basket plexuses around unstained cell bodies. This unique pattern of staining was used to delineate the boundaries of the nucleus and indicated that it is present for much of the rostrocaudal extent of the amygdala. Another region of conspicuous staining on the medial surface of the amygdala was the sulcal portion of the periamygdaloid cortex. This region, associated with the sulcus semiannularis and bordering the entorhinal cortex, consistently contained dense immunoreactivity. The central nucleus also presented a somewhat idiosyncratic pattern of ChAT staining. The lateral subdivision had a diffuse distribution of immunoreactivity in which focal patches of more densely stained terminals and occasional fine fibers were embedded. In contrast, the medial subdivision contained a larger number of thicker, stained fibers without diffuse background labeling.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 400 WORDS)

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: "In the present study, the amygdaloid nuclei are defined according to the nomenclature proposed by Price et al. ('87) for the rat, cat, and monkey. For convenience, the amygdaloid nuclei are grouped into deep nuclei (including basal, accessory basal, lateral, and paralaminar nuclei), superficial structures (including the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract, the periamygdaloid cortex, anterior and posterior cortical nuclei, and the medial nucleus), the central nucleus, and the remaining regions (including the amygdalohippocampal and anterior amygdaloid areas and the intercalated nuclei). Our analysis of the distribution of cholinergic markers in the amygdala has provided additiobal grounds for the subdivision of the basal and accessory basal nuclei and the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract and periamygdaloid cortex. We have therefore made minor modifications to the nomenclature suggested by Price et al. ('87)." (p. 329)

@InterMapRelations.Comments: It should be noticed that the basal amygdaloid nucleus of AB89 has 3 subdivisions (AB89-Bi, -Bmg, Bpc) and that of PRA87 only 2 subdivisions (PRA87-Bmg, -Bpc). Because of (i) the location of the subdivisions and (ii) of the description of cell sizes and immunohistochemistry it seems that AB89-Bi overlaps with PRA87-Bmg and (!) -Bpc and that AB89-Bpc and AB89-Bmg are subparts of PRA87-Bpc and PRA87-Bmg, respectively, because PRA87 didn't describe an intermediate subdivision in contrast to AB89.

(p. 329) "The accessory basal nucleus demonstrated a complex and heterogeneous pattern of staining in all of the histological preparations. Price et al. ('87) recognized three subdivisions of the accessory basal nucleus: a dorsally situated magnocellular subdivision (ABmg), a ventrally situated parvicellular division (ABpc), and a medially situated superficial subdivision (ABs) (Figs. 5,6). In the current study we noted at least two other distinct populations of neurons that stained heavily for ChAT and AChE, which were situated ventromedial to rostral levels of the AB. ...Since the rostrally situated patches appeared different from ABs both cytoarchitectonically and in their ChAT and AChE staining, we have considered them to constitute a separate region of AB and labeled it the ventromedial subdivision (ABvm, Fig. 4). ...The ABs was initially separated from the ABpc primarily because it stained heavily for AChE (Price et al., '87). Our preparations have confirmed this and demonstrate further that the ABs contained a moderate density of ChAT immunoreactive fibers and terminals (Fig. 5). The region ventromedial to the AB demonstrated a highly complex cytoarchitectonic appearance that was paralled by a heterogeneous pattern of AChE and ChAT staining (see Figs. 11D, E, 12). ...We have provisionally considered this cell group to be a subdivision of the AB and have labeled it the ventromedial subdivision (ABvm)." (pp. 340, 349)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: AB89 divided the accessory basal amygdaloid nucleus into four subdivisions (AB89-ABmg, -ABpc, -ABs, and ABvm), whereas PRA87 divided it only into three subdivisions (PRA87-ABmg, -ABpc, and ABs). We understand AB89's description of the different subdivions so that AB89-ABs is in addition to the other 3 subdivisions (ABmg, ABpc, ABs) of AB89-AB, which seem to be identical with the same called nuclei of PRA87. Thus, PRA87-AB contains AB89-AB, because AB89-ABvm is in addition to PRA87-ABmg/pc/s, which are identical with AB89-ABmg/pc/s, respectively.

(p. 329) "The accessory basal nucleus demonstrated a complex and heterogeneous pattern of staining in all of the histological preparations. Price et al. ('87) recognized three subdivisions of the accessory basal nucleus: a dorsally situated magnocellular subdivision (ABmg), a ventrally situated parvicellular division (ABpc), and a medially situated superficial subdivision (ABs) (Figs. 5,6). In the current study we noted at least two other distinct populations of neurons that stained heavily for ChAT and AChE, which were situated ventromedial to rostral levels of the AB. ...Since the rostrally situated patches appeared different from ABs both cytoarchitectonically and in their ChAT and AChE staining, we have considered them to constitute a separate region of AB and labeled it the ventromedial subdivision (ABvm, Fig. 4). ...The ABs was initially separated from the ABpc primarily because it stained heavily for AChE (Price et al., '87). Our preparations have confirmed this and demonstrate further that the ABs contained a moderate density of ChAT immunoreactive fibers and terminals (Fig. 5). The region ventromedial to the AB demonstrated a highly complex cytoarchitectonic appearance that was paralled by a heterogeneous pattern of AChE and ChAT staining (see Figs. 11D, E, 12). ...We have provisionally considered this cell group to be a subdivision of the AB and have labeled it the ventromedial subdivision (ABvm)." (pp. 340, 349)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: AB89 divided the accessory basal amygdaloid nucleus into four subdivisions (AB89-ABmg, -ABpc, -ABs, and ABvm), whereas PRA87 divided it only into three subdivisions (PRA87-ABmg, -ABpc, and ABs). We understand AB89's description of the different subdivions so that AB89-ABs is in addition to the other 3 subdivisions (ABmg, ABpc, ABs) of AB89-AB, which seem to be identical with the same called nuclei of PRA87. Thus, PRA87-AB contains AB89-AB, because AB89-ABvm is in addition to PRA87-ABmg/pc/s, which are identical with AB89-ABmg/pc/s, respectively.

For convenience, the amygdaloid nuclei are grouped into deep nuclei (including basal, accessory basal, lateral, and paralaminar nuclei), superficial structures (including the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract, the periamygdaloid cortex, anterior and posterior cortical nuclei, and the medial nucleus), the central nucleus, and the remaining regions (including the amygdalohippocampal and anterior amygdaloid areas and the intercalated nuclei). Our analysis of the distribution of cholinergic markers in the amygdala has provided additiobal grounds for the subdivision of the basal and accessory basal nuclei and the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract and periamygdaloid cortex. We have therefore made minor modifications to the nomenclature suggested by Price et al. ('87)." (p. 329) "Whereas we have previously divided the basal nucleus into a dorsal magnocellular division and a ventral parvicellular division, in the current analyses we noted in the thionin-stained material and in the ChAT and AChE preparations that there were indications of three dorsoventrally situated subdivisions in the basal nucleus that changed from one to another in a gradual fashion (Figs. 2-7). ...Situated between the Bmg and the parvicellular division (Bpc) was a portion of the basal nucleus that we have labeled the intermediate subdivision (Bi)." (p. 340)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: It should be noticed that the basal amygdaloid nucleus of AB89 has 3 subdivisions (AB89-Bi, -Bmg, Bpc) and that of PRA87 only 2 subdivisions (PRA87-Bmg, -Bpc). Because of (i) the location of the subdivisions and (ii) of the description of cell sizes and immunohistochemistry it seems that AB89-Bi overlaps with PRA87-Bmg and (!) -Bpc and that AB89-Bpc and AB89-Bmg are subparts of PRA87-Bpc and PRA87-Bmg, respectively, because PRA87 didn't describe an intermediate subdivision in contrast to AB89.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "In the present study, the amygdaloid nuclei are defined according to the nomenclature proposed by Price et al. ('87) for the rat, cat, and monkey. For convenience, the amygdaloid nuclei are grouped into deep nuclei (including basal, accessory basal, lateral, and paralaminar nuclei), superficial structures (including the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract, the periamygdaloid cortex, anterior and posterior cortical nuclei, and the medial nucleus), the central nucleus, and the remaining regions (including the amygdalohippocampal and anterior amygdaloid areas and the intercalated nuclei). Our analysis of the distribution of cholinergic markers in the amygdala has provided additiobal grounds for the subdivision of the basal and accessory basal nuclei and the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract and periamygdaloid cortex. We have therefore made minor modifications to the nomenclature suggested by Price et al. ('87)." (p. 329) "Price et al. ('87) distinguished a ventrolateral subdivision (Lvl) from the surrounding dorsomedial region (Ldm) because the former has a higher cell density and increased staining for AChE. In general, the lateral nucleus had the lowest density of ChAT and AChE stained fibers of the deep nuclei and it was only the Lvl that showed appreciable staining for the cholinergic markers (Figs. 5-7). ...In th eposterior half of the lateral nucleus, there was a region containing an increased density of somewhat darker staining neurons that Price et al. ('87) labeled the ventrolateral subdivision (Lvl, Figs. 5-7). ...Another distinctive feature of the lateral nucleus was the occurence of patches of small, tightly packed neurons that contained an extremely dense plexus of ChAT immunoreactive and AChE positive fibers (Fig. 10A-C). Because these cell groups generally occurred along the lateral limit of the lateral nucleus and were often encapsulated by the bundles of fibers running through this area, we called them the lateral capsular nuclei (LCN). The LCN were seen in all of the brains analyzed but varied somewhat in size, shape, and number." (p. 349)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: According to the description of AB89, AB89-Lvl is identical with PRA87-Lvl, but it is not possible to extract any relationship without assumption between the lateral amygdaloid nucleus of AB89 (AB89-L) in the whole and the subdivion Ldm of PRA87, because the subdivision Ldm hasn't been delineated by AB89. It is also important to emphasize, that PRA87 didn't recognize any nucleus correspondingly to AB89-LCN..

(p. 329); "The periamygdaloid cortex (PAC) is a heterogeneous region that covers much of the medial surface of the amygdala. Price et al. ('87) divided the periamygdaloid cortex into four regions based mainly on cytoarchitectonic characteristics. Because of the similarity in staining characteristics for the cholinergic markers, we have combined the areas previously identified as PAC1 and PACs, and called the whole region PACs. ...As noted above, the sulcal portion of the periamygdaloid cortex (PACs) includes what Price et al. ('87) called PAC1 and PACs." (p. 351)

Our analysis of the distribution of cholinergic markers in the amygdala has provided additiobal grounds for the subdivision of the basal and accessory basal nuclei and the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract and periamygdaloid cortex. We have therefore made minor modifications to the nomenclature suggested by Price et al. ('87)." (p. 329); "The periamygdaloid cortex (PAC) is a heterogeneous region that covers much of the medial surface of the amygdala. Price et al. ('87) divided the periamygdaloid cortex into four regions based mainly on cytoarchitectonic characteristics. Because of the similarity in staining characteristics for the cholinergic markers, we have combined the areas previously identified as PAC1 and PACs, and called the whole region PACs. ...As noted above, the sulcal portion of the periamygdaloid cortex (PACs) includes what Price et al. ('87) called PAC1 and PACs." (p. 351)

"The paralaminar nucleus (PL) is located deep to the basal nucleus for much of its rostrocaudal extent and was previously referred to as the paralaminar division of the basal nucleus (Amaral and Price, ' 84; rationale for the name change is included in Price et al., ' 87)." (p. 349)

"The paralaminar nucleus (PL) is located deep to the basal nucleus for much of its rostrocaudal extent and was previously referred to as the paralaminar division of the basal nucleus (Amaral and Price, ' 84; rationale for the name change is included in Price et al., ' 87)." (p. 349)

"In the present study, the amygdaloid nuclei are defined according to the nomenclature proposed by Price et al. ('87) for the rat, cat, and monkey. For convenience, the amygdaloid nuclei are grouped into deep nuclei (including basal, accessory basal, lateral, and paralaminar nuclei), superficial structures (including the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract, the periamygdaloid cortex, anterior and posterior cortical nuclei, and the medial nucleus), the central nucleus, and the remaining regions (including the amygdalohippocampal and anterior amygdaloid areas and the intercalated nuclei). Our analysis of the distribution of cholinergic markers in the amygdala has provided additiobal grounds for the subdivision of the basal and accessory basal nuclei and the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract and periamygdaloid cortex. We have therefore made minor modifications to the nomenclature suggested by Price et al. ('87)." (p. 329); "As noted by Price et al. ('87) the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract (NLOT) has been particularly difficult to identify in the monkey brain. ...The result of this reanalysis is that the NLOT appears to be somewhat more extensive than indicated by Price et al. ('87). ...In general the NLOT had a relatively dense but patchy layer II and a more diffuse layer III. ...We had previously considered that the NLOT ended approximately at a midrostrocaudal level of the amygdala. However, in the current analysis we noted that cells with the characteristic pericellular ChAT immunoreactivity continued caudally in a deeper position, just dorsal to the emerging magnocellular division of the accessory basal nucleus and ventral to the medial nucleus (Figs. 5, 6)." (p. 351)

@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: It should be noticed that the basal amygdaloid nucleus of AB89 has 3 subdivisions (AB89-Bi, -Bmg, Bpc) and that of PRA87 only 2 subdivisions (PRA87-Bmg, -Bpc). Because of (i) the location of the subdivisions and (ii) of the description of cell sizes and immunohistochemistry it seems that AB89-Bi overlaps with PRA87-Bmg and (!) -Bpc and that AB89-Bpc and AB89-Bmg are subparts of PRA87-Bpc and PRA87-Bmg, respectively, because PRA87 didn't describe an intermediate subdivision in contrast to AB89.

For convenience, the amygdaloid nuclei are grouped into deep nuclei (including basal, accessory basal, lateral, and paralaminar nuclei), superficial structures (including the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract, the periamygdaloid cortex, anterior and posterior cortical nuclei, and the medial nucleus), the central nucleus, and the remaining regions (including the amygdalohippocampal and anterior amygdaloid areas and the intercalated nuclei). Our analysis of the distribution of cholinergic markers in the amygdala has provided additiobal grounds for the subdivision of the basal and accessory basal nuclei and the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract and periamygdaloid cortex. We have therefore made minor modifications to the nomenclature suggested by Price et al. ('87)." (p. 329)

"In the present study, the amygdaloid nuclei are defined according to the nomenclature proposed by Price et al. ('87) for the rat, cat, and monkey. For convenience, the amygdaloid nuclei are grouped into deep nuclei (including basal, accessory basal, lateral, and paralaminar nuclei), superficial structures (including the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract, the periamygdaloid cortex, anterior and posterior cortical nuclei, and the medial nucleus), the central nucleus, and the remaining regions (including the amygdalohippocampal and anterior amygdaloid areas and the intercalated nuclei). Our analysis of the distribution of cholinergic markers in the amygdala has provided additiobal grounds for the subdivision of the basal and accessory basal nuclei and the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract and periamygdaloid cortex. We have therefore made minor modifications to the nomenclature suggested by Price et al. ('87)." (p. 329) "The accessory basal nucleus demonstrated a complex and heterogeneous pattern of staining in all of the histological preparations. Price et al. ('87) recognized three subdivisions of the accessory basal nucleus: a dorsally situated magnocellular subdivision (ABmg), a ventrally situated parvicellular division (ABpc), and a medially situated superficial subdivision (ABs) (Figs. 5,6). In the current study we noted at least two other distinct populations of neurons that stained heavily for ChAT and AChE, which were situated ventromedial to rostral levels of the AB. ...Since the rostrally situated patches appeared different from ABs both cytoarchitectonically and in their ChAT and AChE staining, we have considered them to constitute a separate region of AB and labeled it the ventromedial subdivision (ABvm, Fig. 4). ...The ABs was initially separated from the ABpc primarily because it stained heavily for AChE (Price et al., '87). Our preparations have confirmed this and demonstrate further that the ABs contained a moderate density of ChAT immunoreactive fibers and terminals (Fig. 5). The region ventromedial to the AB demonstrated a highly complex cytoarchitectonic appearance that was paralled by a heterogeneous pattern of AChE and ChAT staining (see Figs. 11D, E, 12). ...We have provisionally considered this cell group to be a subdivision of the AB and have labeled it the ventromedial subdivision (ABvm)." (pp. 340, 349)
@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: AB89 divided the accessory basal amygdaloid nucleus into four subdivisions (AB89-ABmg, -ABpc, -ABs, and ABvm), whereas PRA87 divided it only into three subdivisions (PRA87-ABmg, -ABpc, and ABs). We understand AB89's description of the different subdivions so that AB89-ABs is in addition to the other 3 subdivisions (ABmg, ABpc, ABs) of AB89-AB, which seem to be identical with the same called nuclei of PRA87. Thus, PRA87-AB contains AB89-AB, because AB89-ABvm is in addition to PRA87-ABmg/pc/s, which are identical with AB89-ABmg/pc/s, respectively.

(p. 329) "Whereas we have previously divided the basal nucleus into a dorsal magnocellular division and a ventral parvicellular division, in the current analyses we noted in the thionin-stained material and in the ChAT and AChE preparations that there were indications of three dorsoventrally situated subdivisions in the basal nucleus that changed from one to another in a gradual fashion (Figs. 2-7). ...Situated between the Bmg and the parvicellular division (Bpc) was a portion of the basal nucleus that we have labeled the intermediate subdivision (Bi)." (p. 340)
@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: It should be noticed that the basal amygdaloid nucleus of AB89 has 3 subdivisions (AB89-Bi, -Bmg, Bpc) and that of PRA87 only 2 subdivisions (PRA87-Bmg, -Bpc). Because of (i) the location of the subdivisions and (ii) of the description of cell sizes and immunohistochemistry it seems that AB89-Bi overlaps with PRA87-Bmg and (!) -Bpc and that AB89-Bpc and AB89-Bmg are subparts of PRA87-Bpc and PRA87-Bmg, respectively, because PRA87 didn't describe an intermediate subdivision in contrast to AB89.

@InterMapRelations_clean.Citation: "In the present study, the amygdaloid nuclei are defined according to the nomenclature proposed by Price et al. ('87) for the rat, cat, and monkey. For convenience, the amygdaloid nuclei are grouped into deep nuclei (including basal, accessory basal, lateral, and paralaminar nuclei), superficial structures (including the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract, the periamygdaloid cortex, anterior and posterior cortical nuclei, and the medial nucleus), the central nucleus, and the remaining regions (including the amygdalohippocampal and anterior amygdaloid areas and the intercalated nuclei). Our analysis of the distribution of cholinergic markers in the amygdala has provided additiobal grounds for the subdivision of the basal and accessory basal nuclei and the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract and periamygdaloid cortex. We have therefore made minor modifications to the nomenclature suggested by Price et al. ('87)." (p. 329) "Price et al. ('87) distinguished a ventrolateral subdivision (Lvl) from the surrounding dorsomedial region (Ldm) because the former has a higher cell density and increased staining for AChE. In general, the lateral nucleus had the lowest density of ChAT and AChE stained fibers of the deep nuclei and it was only the Lvl that showed appreciable staining for the cholinergic markers (Figs. 5-7). ...In th eposterior half of the lateral nucleus, there was a region containing an increased density of somewhat darker staining neurons that Price et al. ('87) labeled the ventrolateral subdivision (Lvl, Figs. 5-7). ...Another distinctive feature of the lateral nucleus was the occurence of patches of small, tightly packed neurons that contained an extremely dense plexus of ChAT immunoreactive and AChE positive fibers (Fig. 10A-C). Because these cell groups generally occurred along the lateral limit of the lateral nucleus and were often encapsulated by the bundles of fibers running through this area, we called them the lateral capsular nuclei (LCN). The LCN were seen in all of the brains analyzed but varied somewhat in size, shape, and number." (p. 349)
@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: According to the description of AB89, AB89-Lvl is identical with PRA87-Lvl, but it is not possible to extract any relationship without assumption between the lateral amygdaloid nucleus of AB89 (AB89-L) in the whole and the subdivion Ldm of PRA87, because the subdivision Ldm hasn't been delineated by AB89. It is also important to emphasize, that PRA87 didn't recognize any nucleus correspondingly to AB89-LCN..

We have therefore made minor modifications to the nomenclature suggested by Price et al. ('87)." (p. 329); "The periamygdaloid cortex (PAC) is a heterogeneous region that covers much of the medial surface of the amygdala. Price et al. ('87) divided the periamygdaloid cortex into four regions based mainly on cytoarchitectonic characteristics. Because of the similarity in staining characteristics for the cholinergic markers, we have combined the areas previously identified as PAC1 and PACs, and called the whole region PACs. ...As noted above, the sulcal portion of the periamygdaloid cortex (PACs) includes what Price et al. ('87) called PAC1 and PACs." (p. 351)

publication.title: Cholinergic innervation of the monkey amygdala: An immunohistochemical analysis with antisera to choline acetyltransferase
publication.abstract: The organization of the cholinergic innervation of the macaque monkey amygdaloid complex was investigated by means of immunohistochemical techniques and either a polyclonal antiserum or a monoclonal antibody directed against the specific synthetic enzyme choline acetyltransferase (ChAT). Adjacent series of sections were processed histochemically for the demonstration of the degradative enzyme acetylcholinesterase (AChE) or for cell bodies with thionin. The density of ChAT immunoreactivity differed substantially among the various nuclei and cortical regions of the amygdala. In general, the distribution of ChAT immunoreactivity paralleled the pattern of AChE staining. One notable exception was the presence of AChE containing cell bodies in addition to AChE positive fibers within nearly all of the nuclear and cortical regions. In contrast, ChAT immunoreactivity was associated only with fibers and terminals. The highest density of ChAT immunoreactive fibers and terminals was consistently observed in the magnocellular subdivision of the basal nucleus. Staining was substantially less dense in the more ventrally situated parvicellular subdivision. Medially, in the adjacent accessory basal nucleus, immunoreactive fibers and terminals were densest in the magnocellular and superficial subdivisions and least prominent in the parvicellular subdivision. Of the deep nuclei, the lateral nucleus generally obtained the least ChAT immunoreactive terminals and processes. Only its more densely cellular ventrolateral portion contained appreciable fiber and terminal staining. One of the more distinctive patterns of ChAT immunoreactivity was seen in the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract. Here, ChAT positive fibers formed pericellular basket plexuses around unstained cell bodies. This unique pattern of staining was used to delineate the boundaries of the nucleus and indicated that it is present for much of the rostrocaudal extent of the amygdala. Another region of conspicuous staining on the medial surface of the amygdala was the sulcal portion of the periamygdaloid cortex. This region, associated with the sulcus semiannularis and bordering the entorhinal cortex, consistently contained dense immunoreactivity. The central nucleus also presented a somewhat idiosyncratic pattern of ChAT staining. The lateral subdivision had a diffuse distribution of immunoreactivity in which focal patches of more densely stained terminals and occasional fine fibers were embedded. In contrast, the medial subdivision contained a larger number of thicker, stained fibers without diffuse background labeling.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 400 WORDS)
